case_vignette: A 61-year-old male with past medical history of insulin-dependent diabetes, atrial fibrillation not on anticoagulation presents for evaluation of toenail discoloration. He reports a several year history of yellowing and thickening of multiple toenails. He previously was getting his nails clipped at the podiatrist. He has not tried any other treatments. He is an avid swimmer at the local indoor pool. Physical examination reveals hyperkeratotic yellow-white thickening of the bilateral first, second, and third nailplates with significant subungual debris. He denies any rash elsewhere on the body or any history of skin conditions.
question: What is the final diagnosis?

You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've noticed that several of my toenails have become yellow and thickened over the years.
Have you noticed any pain or discomfort in your toes?
No, I haven't felt any pain or discomfort in my toes.
Have you noticed any changes in your overall health or medical history?
I have insulin-dependent diabetes and atrial fibrillation, for which I'm not taking any blood thinners.
Have you noticed any changes in your diet or lifestyle habits?
I'm an avid swimmer and I swim regularly at the local indoor pool.
Have you noticed any changes in your skin or nails in other parts of your body?
No, I haven't seen any rash or skin issues elsewhere on my body.
Have you noticed any changes in your family history of skin or nail conditions?
No, I don't have any history of skin conditions in my family.
Final Diagnosis: Onychomycosis (Fungal Nail Infection)
